segment.source: Respond to keystroke actions from hardware or software keyboards in your apps using both keyboard and class event handlers.
segment.target: Respond to keystroke actions from hardware or software keyboards in your apps using both keyboard and class event handlers.

segment.source: Keyboard interactions
segment.target: Keyboard interactions

segment.source: Keyboard interactions
segment.target: Keyboard interactions

segment.source: Keyboard input is an important part of the overall user interaction experience for apps.
segment.target: Keyboard input is an important part of the overall user interaction experience for apps.

segment.source: The keyboard is indispensable to people with certain disabilities or users who just consider it a more efficient way to interact with an app.
segment.target: The keyboard is indispensable to people with certain disabilities or users who just consider it a more efficient way to interact with an app.

segment.source: For example, users should be able to navigate your app by using Tab and arrow keys, activate UI elements by using Spacebar and Enter, and access commands by using keyboard shortcuts.
segment.target: For example, users should be able to navigate your app by using Tab and arrow keys, activate UI elements by using Spacebar and Enter, and access commands by using keyboard shortcuts.

segment.source: keyboard hero image
segment.target: keyboard hero image

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: KeyDown
segment.target: KeyDown

segment.source: KeyUp
segment.target: KeyUp

segment.source: KeyRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: KeyRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: A well-designed keyboard UI is an important aspect of software accessibility.
segment.target: A well-designed keyboard UI is an important aspect of software accessibility.

segment.source: It enables users with vision impairments or who have certain motor disabilities to navigate an app and interact with its features.
segment.target: It enables users with vision impairments or who have certain motor disabilities to navigate an app and interact with its features.

segment.source: Such users might not be able to operate a mouse and instead rely on various assistive technologies such as keyboard enhancement tools, on-screen keyboards, screen enlargers, screen readers, and voice input utilities.
segment.target: Such users might not be able to operate a mouse and instead rely on various assistive technologies such as keyboard enhancement tools, on-screen keyboards, screen enlargers, screen readers, and voice input utilities.

segment.source: Users can interact with universal apps through a hardware keyboard and two software keyboards: the On-Screen Keyboard (OSK) and the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Users can interact with universal apps through a hardware keyboard and two software keyboards: the On-Screen Keyboard (OSK) and the touch keyboard.

segment.source: On-Screen Keyboard
segment.target: On-Screen Keyboard

segment.source: The On-Screen Keyboard is a visual, software keyboard that you can use instead of the physical keyboard to type and enter data using touch, mouse, pen/stylus or other pointing device (a touch screen is not required).
segment.target: The On-Screen Keyboard is a visual, software keyboard that you can use instead of the physical keyboard to type and enter data using touch, mouse, pen/stylus or other pointing device (a touch screen is not required).

segment.source: The On-Screen Keyboard is provided for systems that don't have a physical keyboard, or for users whose mobility impairments prevent them from using traditional physical input devices.
segment.target: The On-Screen Keyboard is provided for systems that don't have a physical keyboard, or for users whose mobility impairments prevent them from using traditional physical input devices.

segment.source: The On-Screen Keyboard emulates most, if not all, the functionality of a hardware keyboard.
segment.target: The On-Screen Keyboard emulates most, if not all, the functionality of a hardware keyboard.

segment.source: The On-Screen Keyboard can be turned on from the Keyboard page in Settings Ease of access.
segment.target: The On-Screen Keyboard can be turned on from the Keyboard page in Settings Ease of access.

segment.source: Note The On-Screen Keyboard has priority over the touch keyboard, which won't be shown if the On-Screen Keyboard is present.
segment.target: Note The On-Screen Keyboard has priority over the touch keyboard, which won't be shown if the On-Screen Keyboard is present.

segment.source: the on-screen keyboard
segment.target: the on-screen keyboard

segment.source: On-Screen Keyboard
segment.target: On-Screen Keyboard

segment.source: Touch keyboard
segment.target: Touch keyboard

segment.source: The touch keyboard is a visual, software keyboard used for text entry with touch input.
segment.target: The touch keyboard is a visual, software keyboard used for text entry with touch input.

segment.source: It is not a replacement for the On-Screen Keyboard as it's used for text input only (it doesn't emulate the hardware keyboard).
segment.target: It is not a replacement for the On-Screen Keyboard as it's used for text input only (it doesn't emulate the hardware keyboard).

segment.source: Depending on the device, the touch keyboard appears when a text field or other editable text control gets focus, or when the user manually enables it through the Notification Center:
segment.target: Depending on the device, the touch keyboard appears when a text field or other editable text control gets focus, or when the user manually enables it through the Notification Center:

segment.source: touch keyboard icon in the notification center
segment.target: touch keyboard icon in the notification center

segment.source: Note The user might have to go to the Tablet mode screen in Settings System and turn on "Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet" to enable the automatic appearance of the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Note The user might have to go to the Tablet mode screen in Settings System and turn on "Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet" to enable the automatic appearance of the touch keyboard.

segment.source: If your app sets focus programmatically to a text input control, the touch keyboard is not invoked.
segment.target: If your app sets focus programmatically to a text input control, the touch keyboard is not invoked.

segment.source: This eliminates unexpected behaviors not instigated directly by the user.
segment.target: This eliminates unexpected behaviors not instigated directly by the user.

segment.source: However, the keyboard does automatically hide when focus is moved programmatically to a non-text input control.
segment.target: However, the keyboard does automatically hide when focus is moved programmatically to a non-text input control.

segment.source: The touch keyboard typically remains visible while the user navigates between controls in a form.
segment.target: The touch keyboard typically remains visible while the user navigates between controls in a form.

segment.source: This behavior can vary based on the other control types within the form.
segment.target: This behavior can vary based on the other control types within the form.

segment.source: The following is a list of non-edit controls that can receive focus during a text entry session using the touch keyboard without dismissing the keyboard.
segment.target: The following is a list of non-edit controls that can receive focus during a text entry session using the touch keyboard without dismissing the keyboard.

segment.source: Rather than needlessly churn the UI and potentially disorient the user, the touch keyboard remains in view because the user is likely to go back and forth between these controls and text entry with the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Rather than needlessly churn the UI and potentially disorient the user, the touch keyboard remains in view because the user is likely to go back and forth between these controls and text entry with the touch keyboard.

segment.source: Check box
segment.target: Check box

segment.source: Combo box
segment.target: Combo box

segment.source: Radio button
segment.target: Radio button

segment.source: Scroll bar
segment.target: Scroll bar

segment.source: Tree
segment.target: Tree

segment.source: Tree item
segment.target: Tree item

segment.source: Menu
segment.target: Menu

segment.source: Menu bar
segment.target: Menu bar

segment.source: Menu item
segment.target: Menu item

segment.source: Toolbar
segment.target: Toolbar

segment.source: List
segment.target: List

segment.source: List item
segment.target: List item

segment.source: Here are examples of different modes for the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Here are examples of different modes for the touch keyboard.

segment.source: The first image is the default layout, the second is the thumb layout (which might not be available in all languages).
segment.target: The first image is the default layout, the second is the thumb layout (which might not be available in all languages).

segment.source: Here are examples of different modes for the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Here are examples of different modes for the touch keyboard.

segment.source: The first image is the default layout, the second is the thumb layout (which might not be available in all languages).
segment.target: The first image is the default layout, the second is the thumb layout (which might not be available in all languages).

segment.source: The touch keyboard in default layout mode:
segment.target: The touch keyboard in default layout mode:

segment.source: The touch keyboard in expanded layout mode:
segment.target: The touch keyboard in expanded layout mode:

segment.source: The touch keyboard in default thumb layout mode:
segment.target: The touch keyboard in default thumb layout mode:

segment.source: The touch keyboard in numeric thumb layout mode:
segment.target: The touch keyboard in numeric thumb layout mode:

segment.source: Successful keyboard interactions enable users to accomplish basic app scenarios using only the keyboard; that is, users can reach all interactive elements and activate default functionality.
segment.target: Successful keyboard interactions enable users to accomplish basic app scenarios using only the keyboard; that is, users can reach all interactive elements and activate default functionality.

segment.source: A number of factors can affect the degree of success, including keyboard navigation, access keys for accessibility, and accelerator (or shortcut) keys for advanced users.
segment.target: A number of factors can affect the degree of success, including keyboard navigation, access keys for accessibility, and accelerator (or shortcut) keys for advanced users.

segment.source: Note The touch keyboard does not support toggle and most system commands (see Patterns).
segment.target: Note The touch keyboard does not support toggle and most system commands (see Patterns).

segment.source: Navigation
segment.target: Navigation

segment.source: To use a control (including navigation elements) with the keyboard, the control must have focus.
segment.target: To use a control (including navigation elements) with the keyboard, the control must have focus.

segment.source: One way for a control to receive keyboard focus is to make it accessible via tab navigation.
segment.target: One way for a control to receive keyboard focus is to make it accessible via tab navigation.

segment.source: A well designed keyboard navigation model provides a logical and predictable tab order that enables a user to explore and use your app quickly and efficiently.
segment.target: A well designed keyboard navigation model provides a logical and predictable tab order that enables a user to explore and use your app quickly and efficiently.

segment.source: All interactive controls should have tab stops (unless they are in a group), whereas non-interactive controls, such as labels, should not.
segment.target: All interactive controls should have tab stops (unless they are in a group), whereas non-interactive controls, such as labels, should not.

segment.source: A set of related controls can be made into a control group and assigned a single tab stop.
segment.target: A set of related controls can be made into a control group and assigned a single tab stop.

segment.source: Control groups are used for sets of controls that behave like a single control, such as radio buttons.
segment.target: Control groups are used for sets of controls that behave like a single control, such as radio buttons.

segment.source: They can also be used when there too many controls to navigate efficiently with the Tab key alone.
segment.target: They can also be used when there too many controls to navigate efficiently with the Tab key alone.

segment.source: The arrow keys, Home, End, Page Up, and Page Down move input focus among the controls within a group (it is not possible to navigate out of a control group using these keys).
segment.target: The arrow keys, Home, End, Page Up, and Page Down move input focus among the controls within a group (it is not possible to navigate out of a control group using these keys).

segment.source: You should set initial keyboard focus on the element that users will intuitively (or most likely) interact with first when your app starts.
segment.target: You should set initial keyboard focus on the element that users will intuitively (or most likely) interact with first when your app starts.

segment.source: Often, this is the main content view of the app so that a user can immediately start using the arrow keys to scroll the app content.
segment.target: Often, this is the main content view of the app so that a user can immediately start using the arrow keys to scroll the app content.

segment.source: Don’t set initial keyboard focus on an element with potentially negative, or even disastrous, results.
segment.target: Don’t set initial keyboard focus on an element with potentially negative, or even disastrous, results.

segment.source: This can prevent loss of data or system access.
segment.target: This can prevent loss of data or system access.

segment.source: Try to rank and present the most important commands, controls, and content first in both the tab order and the display order (or visual hierarchy).
segment.target: Try to rank and present the most important commands, controls, and content first in both the tab order and the display order (or visual hierarchy).

segment.source: However, the actual display position can depend on the parent layout container and certain properties of the child elements that influence the layout.
segment.target: However, the actual display position can depend on the parent layout container and certain properties of the child elements that influence the layout.

segment.source: In particular, layouts that use a grid metaphor or a table metaphor can have a reading order quite different from the tab order.
segment.target: In particular, layouts that use a grid metaphor or a table metaphor can have a reading order quite different from the tab order.

segment.source: This is not always a problem, but you should test your app's functionality, both as a touchable UI and as a keyboard-accessible UI.
segment.target: This is not always a problem, but you should test your app's functionality, both as a touchable UI and as a keyboard-accessible UI.

segment.source: Tab order should follow reading order, whenever possible.
segment.target: Tab order should follow reading order, whenever possible.

segment.source: This can reduce confusion and is dependent on locale and language.
segment.target: This can reduce confusion and is dependent on locale and language.

segment.source: Associate keyboard buttons with appropriate UI (back and forward buttons) in your app.
segment.target: Associate keyboard buttons with appropriate UI (back and forward buttons) in your app.

segment.source: Try to make navigating back to the start screen of your app and between key content as easy and straightforward as possible.
segment.target: Try to make navigating back to the start screen of your app and between key content as easy and straightforward as possible.

segment.source: Use the arrow keys as keyboard shortcuts for proper inner navigation among child elements of composite elements.
segment.target: Use the arrow keys as keyboard shortcuts for proper inner navigation among child elements of composite elements.

segment.source: If tree view nodes have separate child elements for handling expand–collapse and node activation, use the left and right arrow keys to provide keyboard expand–collapse functionality.
segment.target: If tree view nodes have separate child elements for handling expand–collapse and node activation, use the left and right arrow keys to provide keyboard expand–collapse functionality.

segment.source: This is consistent with the platform controls.
segment.target: This is consistent with the platform controls.

segment.source: Because the touch keyboard occludes a large portion of the screen, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) ensures that the input field with focus scrolls into view as a user navigates through the controls on the form, including controls that are not currently in view.
segment.target: Because the touch keyboard occludes a large portion of the screen, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) ensures that the input field with focus scrolls into view as a user navigates through the controls on the form, including controls that are not currently in view.

segment.source: Custom controls should emulate this behavior.
segment.target: Custom controls should emulate this behavior.

segment.source: a form with and without the touch keyboard showing
segment.target: a form with and without the touch keyboard showing

segment.source: In some cases, there are UI elements that should stay on the screen the entire time.
segment.target: In some cases, there are UI elements that should stay on the screen the entire time.

segment.source: Design the UI so that the form controls are contained in a panning region and the important UI elements are static.
segment.target: Design the UI so that the form controls are contained in a panning region and the important UI elements are static.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: a form that contains areas that should always stay in view
segment.target: a form that contains areas that should always stay in view

segment.source: Activation
segment.target: Activation

segment.source: A control can be activated in a number of different ways, whether it currently has focus or not.
segment.target: A control can be activated in a number of different ways, whether it currently has focus or not.

segment.source: Spacebar, Enter, and Esc
segment.target: Spacebar, Enter, and Esc

segment.source: The spacebar should activate the control with input focus.
segment.target: The spacebar should activate the control with input focus.

segment.source: The Enter key should activate a default control or the control with input focus.
segment.target: The Enter key should activate a default control or the control with input focus.

segment.source: A default control is the control with initial focus or one that responds exclusively to the Enter key (typically it changes with input focus).
segment.target: A default control is the control with initial focus or one that responds exclusively to the Enter key (typically it changes with input focus).

segment.source: In addition, the Esc key should close or exit transitory UI, such as menus and dialogs.
segment.target: In addition, the Esc key should close or exit transitory UI, such as menus and dialogs.

segment.source: The Calculator app shown here uses the spacebar to activate the button with focus, locks the Enter key to the “=” button, and locks the Esc key to the “C” button.
segment.target: The Calculator app shown here uses the spacebar to activate the button with focus, locks the Enter key to the “=” button, and locks the Esc key to the “C” button.

segment.source: the calculator app
segment.target: the calculator app

segment.source: Keyboard modifiers
segment.target: Keyboard modifiers

segment.source: Keyboard modifiers fall into the following categories:
segment.target: Keyboard modifiers fall into the following categories:

segment.source: Category
segment.target: Category

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Shortcut key
segment.target: Shortcut key

segment.source: Perform a common action without UI such as "Ctrl-S" for Save.
segment.target: Perform a common action without UI such as "Ctrl-S" for Save.

segment.source: Implement keyboard shortcuts for key app functionality.
segment.target: Implement keyboard shortcuts for key app functionality.

segment.source: Not every command has, or requires, a shortcut.
segment.target: Not every command has, or requires, a shortcut.

segment.source: Access key/Hot key
segment.target: Access key/Hot key

segment.source: Assigned to every visible, top-level control such as "Alt-F" for the File menu.
segment.target: Assigned to every visible, top-level control such as "Alt-F" for the File menu.

segment.source: An access key does not invoke or activate a command.
segment.target: An access key does not invoke or activate a command.

segment.source: Accelerator key
segment.target: Accelerator key

segment.source: Perform default system or app-defined commands such as "Alt-PrtScrn" for screen capture, "Alt-Tab" to switch apps, or "F1" for help.
segment.target: Perform default system or app-defined commands such as "Alt-PrtScrn" for screen capture, "Alt-Tab" to switch apps, or "F1" for help.

segment.source: A command associated with an accelerator key does not have to be a menu item.
segment.target: A command associated with an accelerator key does not have to be a menu item.

segment.source: Application key/Menu key
segment.target: Application key/Menu key

segment.source: Show context menu.
segment.target: Show context menu.

segment.source: Window key/Command key
segment.target: Window key/Command key

segment.source: Activate system commands such as System Menu, Lock Screen, or Show Desktop.
segment.target: Activate system commands such as System Menu, Lock Screen, or Show Desktop.

segment.source: Access keys and accelerator keys support interaction with controls directly instead of navigating to them using the Tab key.
segment.target: Access keys and accelerator keys support interaction with controls directly instead of navigating to them using the Tab key.

segment.source: While some controls have intrinsic labels, such as command buttons, check boxes, and radio buttons, other controls have external labels, such as list views.
segment.target: While some controls have intrinsic labels, such as command buttons, check boxes, and radio buttons, other controls have external labels, such as list views.

segment.source: For controls with external labels, the access key is assigned to the label, which, when invoked, sets focus to an element or value within the associated control.
segment.target: For controls with external labels, the access key is assigned to the label, which, when invoked, sets focus to an element or value within the associated control.

segment.source: The example here, shows the access keys for the Page Layout tab in Word.
segment.target: The example here, shows the access keys for the Page Layout tab in Word.

segment.source: the access keys for the page layout tab in word
segment.target: the access keys for the page layout tab in word

segment.source: Here, the Indent Left text field value is highlighted after entering the access key identified in the associated label.
segment.target: Here, the Indent Left text field value is highlighted after entering the access key identified in the associated label.

segment.source: the indent left text field value is highlighted after entering the access key identified in the associated label
segment.target: the indent left text field value is highlighted after entering the access key identified in the associated label

segment.source: Usability and accessibility
segment.target: Usability and accessibility

segment.source: A well-designed keyboard interaction experience is an important aspect of software accessibility.
segment.target: A well-designed keyboard interaction experience is an important aspect of software accessibility.

segment.source: It enables users with vision impairments or who have certain motor disabilities to navigate an app and interact with its features.
segment.target: It enables users with vision impairments or who have certain motor disabilities to navigate an app and interact with its features.

segment.source: Such users might be unable to operate a mouse and must, instead, rely on various assistive technologies that include keyboard enhancement tools and on-screen keyboards (along with screen enlargers, screen readers, and voice input utilities).
segment.target: Such users might be unable to operate a mouse and must, instead, rely on various assistive technologies that include keyboard enhancement tools and on-screen keyboards (along with screen enlargers, screen readers, and voice input utilities).

segment.source: For these users, comprehensiveness is more important than consistency.
segment.target: For these users, comprehensiveness is more important than consistency.

segment.source: Experienced users often have a strong preference for using the keyboard, because keyboard-based commands can be entered more quickly and don't require removing their hands from the keyboard.
segment.target: Experienced users often have a strong preference for using the keyboard, because keyboard-based commands can be entered more quickly and don't require removing their hands from the keyboard.

segment.source: For these users, efficiency and consistency are crucial; comprehensiveness is important only for the most frequently used commands.
segment.target: For these users, efficiency and consistency are crucial; comprehensiveness is important only for the most frequently used commands.

segment.source: There are subtle distinctions when designing for usability and accessibility, which is why two different keyboard access mechanisms are supported.
segment.target: There are subtle distinctions when designing for usability and accessibility, which is why two different keyboard access mechanisms are supported.

segment.source: Access keys have the following characteristics:
segment.target: Access keys have the following characteristics:

segment.source: An access key is a shortcut to a UI element in your app.
segment.target: An access key is a shortcut to a UI element in your app.

segment.source: They use the Alt key plus an alphanumeric key.
segment.target: They use the Alt key plus an alphanumeric key.

segment.source: They are primarily for accessibility.
segment.target: They are primarily for accessibility.

segment.source: They are assigned to all menus and most dialog box controls.
segment.target: They are assigned to all menus and most dialog box controls.

segment.source: They aren't intended to be memorized, so they are documented directly in the UI by underlining the corresponding control label character.
segment.target: They aren't intended to be memorized, so they are documented directly in the UI by underlining the corresponding control label character.

segment.source: They have effect only in the current window, and navigate to the corresponding menu item or control.
segment.target: They have effect only in the current window, and navigate to the corresponding menu item or control.

segment.source: They aren't assigned consistently because they can't always be.
segment.target: They aren't assigned consistently because they can't always be.

segment.source: However, access keys should be assigned consistently for commonly used commands, especially commit buttons.
segment.target: However, access keys should be assigned consistently for commonly used commands, especially commit buttons.

segment.source: They are localized.
segment.target: They are localized.

segment.source: Because access keys aren't intended to be memorized, they are assigned to a character that is early in the label to make them easy to find, even if there is a keyword that appears later in the label.
segment.target: Because access keys aren't intended to be memorized, they are assigned to a character that is early in the label to make them easy to find, even if there is a keyword that appears later in the label.

segment.source: In contrast, accelerator keys have the following characteristics:
segment.target: In contrast, accelerator keys have the following characteristics:

segment.source: An accelerator key is a shortcut to an app command.
segment.target: An accelerator key is a shortcut to an app command.

segment.source: They primarily use Ctrl and Function key sequences (Windows system shortcut keys also use Alt+non-alphanumeric keys and the Windows logo key).
segment.target: They primarily use Ctrl and Function key sequences (Windows system shortcut keys also use Alt+non-alphanumeric keys and the Windows logo key).

segment.source: They are primarily for efficiency for advanced users.
segment.target: They are primarily for efficiency for advanced users.

segment.source: They are assigned only to the most commonly used commands.
segment.target: They are assigned only to the most commonly used commands.

segment.source: They are intended to be memorized, and are documented only in menus, tooltips, and Help.
segment.target: They are intended to be memorized, and are documented only in menus, tooltips, and Help.

segment.source: They have effect throughout the entire program, but have no effect if they don't apply.
segment.target: They have effect throughout the entire program, but have no effect if they don't apply.

segment.source: They must be assigned consistently because they are memorized and not directly documented.
segment.target: They must be assigned consistently because they are memorized and not directly documented.

segment.source: They aren't localized.
segment.target: They aren't localized.

segment.source: Because accelerator keys are intended to be memorized, the most frequently used accelerator keys ideally use letters from the first or most memorable characters within the command's keywords, such as Ctrl+C for Copy and Ctrl+Q for Request.
segment.target: Because accelerator keys are intended to be memorized, the most frequently used accelerator keys ideally use letters from the first or most memorable characters within the command's keywords, such as Ctrl+C for Copy and Ctrl+Q for Request.

segment.source: Users should be able to accomplish all tasks supported by your app using only the hardware keyboard or the On-Screen Keyboard.
segment.target: Users should be able to accomplish all tasks supported by your app using only the hardware keyboard or the On-Screen Keyboard.

segment.source: You should provide an easy way for users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technology to discover your app's accelerator keys.
segment.target: You should provide an easy way for users who rely on screen readers and other assistive technology to discover your app's accelerator keys.

segment.source: Communicate accelerator keys by using tooltips, accessible names, accessible descriptions, or some other form of on-screen communication.
segment.target: Communicate accelerator keys by using tooltips, accessible names, accessible descriptions, or some other form of on-screen communication.

segment.source: At a minimum, access and accelerator keys should be well documented in your app's Help content.
segment.target: At a minimum, access and accelerator keys should be well documented in your app's Help content.

segment.source: Don’t assign well-known or standard accelerator keys to other functionality.
segment.target: Don’t assign well-known or standard accelerator keys to other functionality.

segment.source: For example, Ctrl+F is typically used for find or search.
segment.target: For example, Ctrl+F is typically used for find or search.

segment.source: Don’t bother trying to assign access keys to all interactive controls in a dense UI.
segment.target: Don’t bother trying to assign access keys to all interactive controls in a dense UI.

segment.source: Just ensure the most important and the most used have access keys, or use control groups and assign an access key to the control group label.
segment.target: Just ensure the most important and the most used have access keys, or use control groups and assign an access key to the control group label.

segment.source: Don't change commands using keyboard modifiers.
segment.target: Don't change commands using keyboard modifiers.

segment.source: Doing so is undiscoverable and can cause confusion.
segment.target: Doing so is undiscoverable and can cause confusion.

segment.source: Don't disable a control while it has input focus.
segment.target: Don't disable a control while it has input focus.

segment.source: This can interfere with keyboard input.
segment.target: This can interfere with keyboard input.

segment.source: To ensure successful keyboard interaction experiences, it is critical to test your app thoroughly and exclusively with the keyboard.
segment.target: To ensure successful keyboard interaction experiences, it is critical to test your app thoroughly and exclusively with the keyboard.

segment.source: Text input
segment.target: Text input

segment.source: Always query the device capabilities when relying on keyboard input.
segment.target: Always query the device capabilities when relying on keyboard input.

segment.source: On some devices (such as phone), the touch keyboard can only be used for text input as it does not provide many of the accelerators or command keys found on a hardware keyboard (such as alt, the function keys, or the Windows Logo key).
segment.target: On some devices (such as phone), the touch keyboard can only be used for text input as it does not provide many of the accelerators or command keys found on a hardware keyboard (such as alt, the function keys, or the Windows Logo key).

segment.source: Don't make users navigate the app using the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Don't make users navigate the app using the touch keyboard.

segment.source: Depending on the control getting focus, the touch keyboard might get dismissed.
segment.target: Depending on the control getting focus, the touch keyboard might get dismissed.

segment.source: Try to display the keyboard throughout the entire interaction with your form.
segment.target: Try to display the keyboard throughout the entire interaction with your form.

segment.source: This eliminates UI churn that can disorient the user in the middle of a form or text entry flow.
segment.target: This eliminates UI churn that can disorient the user in the middle of a form or text entry flow.

segment.source: Ensure that users can always see the input field that they're typing into.
segment.target: Ensure that users can always see the input field that they're typing into.

segment.source: The touch keyboard occludes half of the screen, so the input field with focus should scroll into view as the user traverses the form.
segment.target: The touch keyboard occludes half of the screen, so the input field with focus should scroll into view as the user traverses the form.

segment.source: A standard hardware keyboard or OSK consists of seven types of keys, each supporting unique functionality:
segment.target: A standard hardware keyboard or OSK consists of seven types of keys, each supporting unique functionality:

segment.source: Character key: sends a literal character to the window with input focus.
segment.target: Character key: sends a literal character to the window with input focus.

segment.source: Modifier key: alters the function of a primary key when pressed simultaneously, such as Ctrl, Alt, Shift, and the Windows logo key.
segment.target: Modifier key: alters the function of a primary key when pressed simultaneously, such as Ctrl, Alt, Shift, and the Windows logo key.

segment.source: Navigation key: moves input focus or text input location, such as the Tab, Home, End, Page Up, Page Down, and directional arrow keys.
segment.target: Navigation key: moves input focus or text input location, such as the Tab, Home, End, Page Up, Page Down, and directional arrow keys.

segment.source: Editing key: manipulates text, such as the Shift, Tab, Enter, Insert, Backspace, and Delete keys.
segment.target: Editing key: manipulates text, such as the Shift, Tab, Enter, Insert, Backspace, and Delete keys.

segment.source: Function key: performs a special function, such as F1 through F12 keys.
segment.target: Function key: performs a special function, such as F1 through F12 keys.

segment.source: Toggle key: puts the system into a mode, such as Caps Lock, ScrLk, and Num Lock keys.
segment.target: Toggle key: puts the system into a mode, such as Caps Lock, ScrLk, and Num Lock keys.

segment.source: Command key: performs a system task or command activation, such as Spacebar, Enter, Esc, Pause/Break, and Print Screen keys.
segment.target: Command key: performs a system task or command activation, such as Spacebar, Enter, Esc, Pause/Break, and Print Screen keys.

segment.source: In addition to these categories, a secondary class of keys and key combinations exist that can be used as shortcuts to app functionality:
segment.target: In addition to these categories, a secondary class of keys and key combinations exist that can be used as shortcuts to app functionality:

segment.source: Access key: exposes controls or menu items by pressing the Alt key with a character key, indicated by underlining of the access key character assignment in a menu, or displaying of the access key character(s) in an overlay.
segment.target: Access key: exposes controls or menu items by pressing the Alt key with a character key, indicated by underlining of the access key character assignment in a menu, or displaying of the access key character(s) in an overlay.

segment.source: Accelerator key: exposes app commands by pressing a function key or the Ctrl key with a character key.
segment.target: Accelerator key: exposes app commands by pressing a function key or the Ctrl key with a character key.

segment.source: Your app might or might not have UI that corresponds to the command.
segment.target: Your app might or might not have UI that corresponds to the command.

segment.source: Another class of key combinations, known as secure attention sequence (SAS), cannot be intercepted by an app.
segment.target: Another class of key combinations, known as secure attention sequence (SAS), cannot be intercepted by an app.

segment.source: This is a security feature intended to protect the user's system during login, and include Ctrl-Alt-Del and Win-L.
segment.target: This is a security feature intended to protect the user's system during login, and include Ctrl-Alt-Del and Win-L.

segment.source: The Notepad app is shown here with the expanded File menu that includes both access keys and accelerator keys.
segment.target: The Notepad app is shown here with the expanded File menu that includes both access keys and accelerator keys.

segment.source: the notepad app with expanded file menu that includes both access keys and accelerator keys.
segment.target: the notepad app with expanded file menu that includes both access keys and accelerator keys.

segment.source: Keyboard commands
segment.target: Keyboard commands

segment.source: The following is a comprehensive list of the keyboard interactions provided across the various devices that support keyboard input.
segment.target: The following is a comprehensive list of the keyboard interactions provided across the various devices that support keyboard input.

segment.source: Some devices and platforms require native keystrokes and interactions, these are noted.
segment.target: Some devices and platforms require native keystrokes and interactions, these are noted.

segment.source: When designing custom controls and interactions, use this keyboard language consistently to make your app feel familiar, dependable, and easy to learn.
segment.target: When designing custom controls and interactions, use this keyboard language consistently to make your app feel familiar, dependable, and easy to learn.

segment.source: Don't redefine the default keyboard shortcuts.
segment.target: Don't redefine the default keyboard shortcuts.

segment.source: The following tables list frequently used keyboard commands.
segment.target: The following tables list frequently used keyboard commands.

segment.source: For a complete list of keyboard commands, see Windows Keyboard Shortcut Keys.
segment.target: For a complete list of keyboard commands, see Windows Keyboard Shortcut Keys.

segment.source: Note: The media navigation key commands for Play/Pause and Next item are the same as the key commands for Print and Find, respectively.
segment.target: Note: The media navigation key commands for Play/Pause and Next item are the same as the key commands for Print and Find, respectively.

segment.source: Common commands should take priority over media navigation commands.
segment.target: Common commands should take priority over media navigation commands.

segment.source: For example, if an app supports both plays media and prints, the key command Ctrl+P should print.
segment.target: For example, if an app supports both plays media and prints, the key command Ctrl+P should print.

segment.source: Visual feedback
segment.target: Visual feedback

segment.source: Use focus rectangles only with keyboard interactions.
segment.target: Use focus rectangles only with keyboard interactions.

segment.source: If the user initiates a touch interaction, make the keyboard UI gradually fade away.
segment.target: If the user initiates a touch interaction, make the keyboard UI gradually fade away.

segment.source: This keeps the UI clean and uncluttered.
segment.target: This keeps the UI clean and uncluttered.

segment.source: Don't display visual feedback if an element doesn't support interaction (such as static text).
segment.target: Don't display visual feedback if an element doesn't support interaction (such as static text).

segment.source: Again, this keeps the UI clean and uncluttered.
segment.target: Again, this keeps the UI clean and uncluttered.

segment.source: Try to display visual feedback concurrently for all elements that represent the same input target.
segment.target: Try to display visual feedback concurrently for all elements that represent the same input target.

segment.source: Try to provide on-screen buttons (such as + and -) as hints for emulating touch-based manipulations such as panning, rotating, zooming, and so on.
segment.target: Try to provide on-screen buttons (such as + and -) as hints for emulating touch-based manipulations such as panning, rotating, zooming, and so on.

segment.source: For more general guidance on visual feedback, see Guidelines for visual feedback.
segment.target: For more general guidance on visual feedback, see Guidelines for visual feedback.

segment.source: Keyboard events and focus
segment.target: Keyboard events and focus

segment.source: The following keyboard events can occur for both hardware and touch keyboards.
segment.target: The following keyboard events can occur for both hardware and touch keyboards.

segment.source: Event
segment.target: Event

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: KeyDown
segment.target: KeyDown

segment.source: Occurs when a key is pressed.
segment.target: Occurs when a key is pressed.

segment.source: KeyUp
segment.target: KeyUp

segment.source: Occurs when a key is released.
segment.target: Occurs when a key is released.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Some Windows Runtime controls handle input events internally.
segment.target: Some Windows Runtime controls handle input events internally.

segment.source: In these cases, it might appear that an input event doesn't occur because your event listener doesn't invoke the associated handler.
segment.target: In these cases, it might appear that an input event doesn't occur because your event listener doesn't invoke the associated handler.

segment.source: Typically, this subset of keys is processed by the class handler to provide built in support of basic keyboard accessibility.
segment.target: Typically, this subset of keys is processed by the class handler to provide built in support of basic keyboard accessibility.

segment.source: For example, the Button class overrides the OnKeyDown events for both the Space key and the Enter key (as well as OnPointerPressed) and routes them to the Click event of the control.
segment.target: For example, the Button class overrides the OnKeyDown events for both the Space key and the Enter key (as well as OnPointerPressed) and routes them to the Click event of the control.

segment.source: When a key press is handled by the control class, the KeyDown and KeyUp events are not raised.
segment.target: When a key press is handled by the control class, the KeyDown and KeyUp events are not raised.

segment.source: This provides a built-in keyboard equivalent for invoking the button, similar to tapping it with a finger or clicking it with a mouse.
segment.target: This provides a built-in keyboard equivalent for invoking the button, similar to tapping it with a finger or clicking it with a mouse.

segment.source: Keys other than Space or Enter still fire KeyDown and KeyUp events.
segment.target: Keys other than Space or Enter still fire KeyDown and KeyUp events.

segment.source: For more info about how class-based handling of events works (specifically, the "Input event handlers in controls" section), see Events and routed events overview.
segment.target: For more info about how class-based handling of events works (specifically, the "Input event handlers in controls" section), see Events and routed events overview.

segment.source: Controls in your UI generate keyboard events only when they have input focus.
segment.target: Controls in your UI generate keyboard events only when they have input focus.

segment.source: An individual control gains focus when the user clicks or taps directly on that control in the layout, or uses the Tab key to step into a tab sequence within the content area.
segment.target: An individual control gains focus when the user clicks or taps directly on that control in the layout, or uses the Tab key to step into a tab sequence within the content area.

segment.source: You can also call a control's Focus method to force focus.
segment.target: You can also call a control's Focus method to force focus.

segment.source: This is necessary when you implement shortcut keys, because keyboard focus is not set by default when your UI loads.
segment.target: This is necessary when you implement shortcut keys, because keyboard focus is not set by default when your UI loads.

segment.source: For more info, see the Shortcut keys example later in this topic.
segment.target: For more info, see the Shortcut keys example later in this topic.

segment.source: For a control to receive input focus, it must be enabled, visible, and have IsTabStop and HitTestVisible property values of true.
segment.target: For a control to receive input focus, it must be enabled, visible, and have IsTabStop and HitTestVisible property values of true.

segment.source: This is the default state for most controls.
segment.target: This is the default state for most controls.

segment.source: When a control has input focus, it can raise and respond to keyboard input events as described later in this topic.
segment.target: When a control has input focus, it can raise and respond to keyboard input events as described later in this topic.

segment.source: You can also respond to a control that is receiving or losing focus by handling the GotFocus and LostFocus events.
segment.target: You can also respond to a control that is receiving or losing focus by handling the GotFocus and LostFocus events.

segment.source: By default, the tab sequence of controls is the order in which they appear in the Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).
segment.target: By default, the tab sequence of controls is the order in which they appear in the Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).

segment.source: However, you can modify this order by using the TabIndex property.
segment.target: However, you can modify this order by using the TabIndex property.

segment.source: For more info, see Implementing keyboard accessibility.
segment.target: For more info, see Implementing keyboard accessibility.

segment.source: Keyboard event handlers
segment.target: Keyboard event handlers

segment.source: An input event handler implements a delegate that provides the following information:
segment.target: An input event handler implements a delegate that provides the following information:

segment.source: The sender of the event.
segment.target: The sender of the event.

segment.source: The sender reports the object where the event handler is attached.
segment.target: The sender reports the object where the event handler is attached.

segment.source: Event data.
segment.target: Event data.

segment.source: For keyboard events, that data will be an instance of KeyRoutedEventArgs.
segment.target: For keyboard events, that data will be an instance of KeyRoutedEventArgs.

segment.source: The delegate for handlers is KeyEventHandler.
segment.target: The delegate for handlers is KeyEventHandler.

segment.source: The most relevant properties of KeyRoutedEventArgs for most handler scenarios are Key and possibly KeyStatus.
segment.target: The most relevant properties of KeyRoutedEventArgs for most handler scenarios are Key and possibly KeyStatus.

segment.source: OriginalSource .
segment.target: OriginalSource .

segment.source: Because the keyboard events are routed events, the event data provides OriginalSource.
segment.target: Because the keyboard events are routed events, the event data provides OriginalSource.

segment.source: If you deliberately allow events to bubble up through an object tree, OriginalSource is sometimes the object of concern rather than sender.
segment.target: If you deliberately allow events to bubble up through an object tree, OriginalSource is sometimes the object of concern rather than sender.

segment.source: However, that depends on your design.
segment.target: However, that depends on your design.

segment.source: For more information about how you might use OriginalSource rather than sender, see the "Keyboard Routed Events" section of this topic, or Events and routed events overview.
segment.target: For more information about how you might use OriginalSource rather than sender, see the "Keyboard Routed Events" section of this topic, or Events and routed events overview.

segment.source: Attaching a keyboard event handler
segment.target: Attaching a keyboard event handler

segment.source: You can attach keyboard event-handler functions for any object that includes the event as a member.
segment.target: You can attach keyboard event-handler functions for any object that includes the event as a member.

segment.source: This includes any UIElement derived class.
segment.target: This includes any UIElement derived class.

segment.source: The following XAML example shows how to attach handlers for the KeyUp event for a Grid.
segment.target: The following XAML example shows how to attach handlers for the KeyUp event for a Grid.

segment.source: You can also attach an event handler in code.
segment.target: You can also attach an event handler in code.

segment.source: For more info, see Events and routed events overview.
segment.target: For more info, see Events and routed events overview.

segment.source: Defining a keyboard event handler
segment.target: Defining a keyboard event handler

segment.source: The following example shows the incomplete event handler definition for the KeyUp event handler that was attached in the preceding example.
segment.target: The following example shows the incomplete event handler definition for the KeyUp event handler that was attached in the preceding example.

segment.source: Using KeyRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: Using KeyRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: All keyboard events use KeyRoutedEventArgs for event data, and KeyRoutedEventArgs contains the following properties:
segment.target: All keyboard events use KeyRoutedEventArgs for event data, and KeyRoutedEventArgs contains the following properties:

segment.source: Key
segment.target: Key

segment.source: KeyStatus
segment.target: KeyStatus

segment.source: Handled
segment.target: Handled

segment.source: OriginalSource (inherited from RoutedEventArgs)
segment.target: OriginalSource (inherited from RoutedEventArgs)

segment.source: Key
segment.target: Key

segment.source: The KeyDown event is raised if a key is pressed.
segment.target: The KeyDown event is raised if a key is pressed.

segment.source: Likewise, KeyUp is raised if a key is released.
segment.target: Likewise, KeyUp is raised if a key is released.

segment.source: Usually, you listen to the events to process a specific key value.
segment.target: Usually, you listen to the events to process a specific key value.

segment.source: To determine which key is pressed or released, check the Key value in the event data.
segment.target: To determine which key is pressed or released, check the Key value in the event data.

segment.source: Key returns a VirtualKey value.
segment.target: Key returns a VirtualKey value.

segment.source: The VirtualKey enumeration includes all the supported keys.
segment.target: The VirtualKey enumeration includes all the supported keys.

segment.source: Modifier keys
segment.target: Modifier keys

segment.source: Modifier keys are keys such as Ctrl or Shift that users typically press in combination with other keys.
segment.target: Modifier keys are keys such as Ctrl or Shift that users typically press in combination with other keys.

segment.source: Your app can use these combinations as keyboard shortcuts to invoke app commands.
segment.target: Your app can use these combinations as keyboard shortcuts to invoke app commands.

segment.source: You detect shortcut key combinations by using code in your KeyDown and KeyUp event handlers.
segment.target: You detect shortcut key combinations by using code in your KeyDown and KeyUp event handlers.

segment.source: You can then track the pressed state of the modifier keys you are interested in.
segment.target: You can then track the pressed state of the modifier keys you are interested in.

segment.source: When a keyboard event occurs for a non-modifier key, you can check whether a modifier key is in the pressed state at the same time.
segment.target: When a keyboard event occurs for a non-modifier key, you can check whether a modifier key is in the pressed state at the same time.

segment.source: Note The Alt key is represented by the VirtualKey.Menu value.
segment.target: Note The Alt key is represented by the VirtualKey.Menu value.

segment.source: Shortcut keys example
segment.target: Shortcut keys example

segment.source: The following example demonstrates how to implement shortcut keys.
segment.target: The following example demonstrates how to implement shortcut keys.

segment.source: In this example, users can control media playback using Play, Pause, and Stop buttons or Ctrl+P, Ctrl+A, and Ctrl+S keyboard shortcuts.
segment.target: In this example, users can control media playback using Play, Pause, and Stop buttons or Ctrl+P, Ctrl+A, and Ctrl+S keyboard shortcuts.

segment.source: The button XAML shows the shortcuts by using tooltips and AutomationProperties properties in the button labels.
segment.target: The button XAML shows the shortcuts by using tooltips and AutomationProperties properties in the button labels.

segment.source: This self-documentation is important to increase the usability and accessibility of your app.
segment.target: This self-documentation is important to increase the usability and accessibility of your app.

segment.source: For more info, see Keyboard accessibility.
segment.target: For more info, see Keyboard accessibility.

segment.source: Note also that the page sets input focus to itself when it is loaded.
segment.target: Note also that the page sets input focus to itself when it is loaded.

segment.source: Without this step, no control has initial input focus, and the app does not raise input events until the user sets the input focus manually (for example, by tabbing to or clicking a control).
segment.target: Without this step, no control has initial input focus, and the app does not raise input events until the user sets the input focus manually (for example, by tabbing to or clicking a control).

segment.source: Note Setting AutomationProperties.AcceleratorKey or AutomationProperties.AccessKey in XAML provides string information, which documents the shortcut key for invoking that particular action.
segment.target: Note Setting AutomationProperties.AcceleratorKey or AutomationProperties.AccessKey in XAML provides string information, which documents the shortcut key for invoking that particular action.

segment.source: The information is captured by Microsoft UI Automation clients such as Narrator, and is typically provided directly to the user.
segment.target: The information is captured by Microsoft UI Automation clients such as Narrator, and is typically provided directly to the user.

segment.source: Setting AutomationProperties.AcceleratorKey or AutomationProperties.AccessKey does not have any action on its own.
segment.target: Setting AutomationProperties.AcceleratorKey or AutomationProperties.AccessKey does not have any action on its own.

segment.source: You will still need to attach handlers for KeyDown or KeyUp events in order to actually implement the keyboard shortcut behavior in your app.
segment.target: You will still need to attach handlers for KeyDown or KeyUp events in order to actually implement the keyboard shortcut behavior in your app.

segment.source: Also, the underline text decoration for an access key is not provided automatically.
segment.target: Also, the underline text decoration for an access key is not provided automatically.

segment.source: You must explicitly underline the text for the specific key in your mnemonic as inline Underline formatting if you wish to show underlined text in the UI.
segment.target: You must explicitly underline the text for the specific key in your mnemonic as inline Underline formatting if you wish to show underlined text in the UI.

segment.source: Keyboard routed events
segment.target: Keyboard routed events

segment.source: Certain events are routed events, including KeyDown and KeyUp.
segment.target: Certain events are routed events, including KeyDown and KeyUp.

segment.source: Routed events use the bubbling routing strategy.
segment.target: Routed events use the bubbling routing strategy.

segment.source: The bubbling routing strategy means that an event originates from a child object and is then routed up to successive parent objects in the object tree.
segment.target: The bubbling routing strategy means that an event originates from a child object and is then routed up to successive parent objects in the object tree.

segment.source: This presents another opportunity to handle the same event and interact with the same event data.
segment.target: This presents another opportunity to handle the same event and interact with the same event data.

segment.source: Consider the following XAML example, which handles KeyUp events for a Canvas and two Button objects.
segment.target: Consider the following XAML example, which handles KeyUp events for a Canvas and two Button objects.

segment.source: In this case, if you release a key while focus is held by either Button object, it raises the KeyUp event.
segment.target: In this case, if you release a key while focus is held by either Button object, it raises the KeyUp event.

segment.source: The event is then bubbled up to the parent Canvas.
segment.target: The event is then bubbled up to the parent Canvas.

segment.source: The following example shows how to implement the KeyUp event handler for the corresponding XAML content in the preceding example.
segment.target: The following example shows how to implement the KeyUp event handler for the corresponding XAML content in the preceding example.

segment.source: Notice the use of the OriginalSource property in the preceding handler.
segment.target: Notice the use of the OriginalSource property in the preceding handler.

segment.source: Here, OriginalSource reports the object that raised the event.
segment.target: Here, OriginalSource reports the object that raised the event.

segment.source: The object could not be the StackPanel because the StackPanel is not a control and cannot have focus.
segment.target: The object could not be the StackPanel because the StackPanel is not a control and cannot have focus.

segment.source: Only one of the two buttons within the StackPanel could possibly have raised the event, but which one?
segment.target: Only one of the two buttons within the StackPanel could possibly have raised the event, but which one?

segment.source: You use OriginalSource to distinguish the actual event source object, if you are handling the event on a parent object.
segment.target: You use OriginalSource to distinguish the actual event source object, if you are handling the event on a parent object.

segment.source: The Handled property in event data
segment.target: The Handled property in event data

segment.source: Depending on your event handling strategy, you might want only one event handler to react to a bubbling event.
segment.target: Depending on your event handling strategy, you might want only one event handler to react to a bubbling event.

segment.source: For instance, if you have a specific KeyUp handler attached to one of the Button controls, it would have the first opportunity to handle that event.
segment.target: For instance, if you have a specific KeyUp handler attached to one of the Button controls, it would have the first opportunity to handle that event.

segment.source: In this case, you might not want the parent panel to also handle the event.
segment.target: In this case, you might not want the parent panel to also handle the event.

segment.source: For this scenario, you can use the Handled property in the event data.
segment.target: For this scenario, you can use the Handled property in the event data.

segment.source: The purpose of the Handled property in a routed event data class is to report that another handler you registered earlier on the event route has already acted.
segment.target: The purpose of the Handled property in a routed event data class is to report that another handler you registered earlier on the event route has already acted.

segment.source: This influences the behavior of the routed event system.
segment.target: This influences the behavior of the routed event system.

segment.source: When you set Handled to true in an event handler, that event stops routing and is not sent to successive parent elements.
segment.target: When you set Handled to true in an event handler, that event stops routing and is not sent to successive parent elements.

segment.source: AddHandler and already-handled keyboard events
segment.target: AddHandler and already-handled keyboard events

segment.source: You can use a special technique for attaching handlers that can act on events that you already marked as handled.
segment.target: You can use a special technique for attaching handlers that can act on events that you already marked as handled.

segment.source: This technique uses the AddHandler method to register a handler, rather than using XAML attributes or language-specific syntax for adding handlers, such as += in C. A limitation of this technique in general is that the AddHandler API takes a parameter of type RoutedEvent that identifies the routed event in question.
segment.target: This technique uses the AddHandler method to register a handler, rather than using XAML attributes or language-specific syntax for adding handlers, such as += in C. A limitation of this technique in general is that the AddHandler API takes a parameter of type RoutedEvent that identifies the routed event in question.

segment.source: Not all routed events provide a RoutedEvent identifier, and this consideration thus affects which routed events can still be handled in the Handled case.
segment.target: Not all routed events provide a RoutedEvent identifier, and this consideration thus affects which routed events can still be handled in the Handled case.

segment.source: The KeyDown and KeyUp events have routed event identifiers (KeyDownEvent and KeyUpEvent) on UIElement.
segment.target: The KeyDown and KeyUp events have routed event identifiers (KeyDownEvent and KeyUpEvent) on UIElement.

segment.source: However, other events such as TextBox.TextChanged do not have routed event identifiers and thus cannot be used with the AddHandler technique.
segment.target: However, other events such as TextBox.TextChanged do not have routed event identifiers and thus cannot be used with the AddHandler technique.

segment.source: Commanding
segment.target: Commanding

segment.source: A small number of UI elements provide built-in support for commanding.
segment.target: A small number of UI elements provide built-in support for commanding.

segment.source: Commanding uses input-related routed events in its underlying implementation.
segment.target: Commanding uses input-related routed events in its underlying implementation.

segment.source: It enables processing of related UI input, such as a certain pointer action or a specific accelerator key, by invoking a single command handler.
segment.target: It enables processing of related UI input, such as a certain pointer action or a specific accelerator key, by invoking a single command handler.

segment.source: If commanding is available for a UI element, consider using its commanding APIs instead of any discrete input events.
segment.target: If commanding is available for a UI element, consider using its commanding APIs instead of any discrete input events.

segment.source: For more info, see ButtonBase.Command.
segment.target: For more info, see ButtonBase.Command.

segment.source: You can also implement ICommand to encapsulate command functionality that you invoke from ordinary event handlers.
segment.target: You can also implement ICommand to encapsulate command functionality that you invoke from ordinary event handlers.

segment.source: This enables you to use commanding even when there is no Command property available.
segment.target: This enables you to use commanding even when there is no Command property available.

segment.source: Text input and controls
segment.target: Text input and controls

segment.source: Certain controls react to keyboard events with their own handling.
segment.target: Certain controls react to keyboard events with their own handling.

segment.source: For instance, TextBox is a control that is designed to capture and then visually represent text that was entered by using the keyboard.
segment.target: For instance, TextBox is a control that is designed to capture and then visually represent text that was entered by using the keyboard.

segment.source: It uses KeyUp and KeyDown in its own logic to capture keystrokes, then also raises its own TextChanged event if the text actually changed.
segment.target: It uses KeyUp and KeyDown in its own logic to capture keystrokes, then also raises its own TextChanged event if the text actually changed.

segment.source: You can still generally add handlers for KeyUp and KeyDown to a TextBox, or any related control that is intended to process text input.
segment.target: You can still generally add handlers for KeyUp and KeyDown to a TextBox, or any related control that is intended to process text input.

segment.source: However, as part of its intended design, a control might not respond to all key values that are directed to it through key events.
segment.target: However, as part of its intended design, a control might not respond to all key values that are directed to it through key events.

segment.source: Behavior is specific to each control.
segment.target: Behavior is specific to each control.

segment.source: As an example, ButtonBase (the base class for Button) processes KeyUp so that it can check for the Spacebar or Enter key.
segment.target: As an example, ButtonBase (the base class for Button) processes KeyUp so that it can check for the Spacebar or Enter key.

segment.source: ButtonBase considers KeyUp equivalent to a mouse left button down for purposes of raising a Click event.
segment.target: ButtonBase considers KeyUp equivalent to a mouse left button down for purposes of raising a Click event.

segment.source: This processing of the event is accomplished when ButtonBase overrides the virtual method OnKeyUp.
segment.target: This processing of the event is accomplished when ButtonBase overrides the virtual method OnKeyUp.

segment.source: In its implementation, it sets Handled to true.
segment.target: In its implementation, it sets Handled to true.

segment.source: The result is that any parent of a button that is listening for a key event, in the case of a Spacebar, would not receive the already-handled event for its own handlers.
segment.target: The result is that any parent of a button that is listening for a key event, in the case of a Spacebar, would not receive the already-handled event for its own handlers.

segment.source: Another example is TextBox.
segment.target: Another example is TextBox.

segment.source: Some keys, such as the ARROW keys, are not considered text by TextBox and are instead considered specific to the control UI behavior.
segment.target: Some keys, such as the ARROW keys, are not considered text by TextBox and are instead considered specific to the control UI behavior.

segment.source: The TextBox marks these event cases as handled.
segment.target: The TextBox marks these event cases as handled.

segment.source: Custom controls can implement their own similar override behavior for key events by overriding OnKeyDownOnKeyUp.
segment.target: Custom controls can implement their own similar override behavior for key events by overriding OnKeyDownOnKeyUp.

segment.source: If your custom control processes specific accelerator keys, or has control or focus behavior that is similar to the scenario described for TextBox, you should place this logic in your own OnKeyDownOnKeyUp overrides.
segment.target: If your custom control processes specific accelerator keys, or has control or focus behavior that is similar to the scenario described for TextBox, you should place this logic in your own OnKeyDownOnKeyUp overrides.

segment.source: The touch keyboard
segment.target: The touch keyboard

segment.source: Text input controls provide automatic support for the touch keyboard.
segment.target: Text input controls provide automatic support for the touch keyboard.

segment.source: When the user sets the input focus to a text control by using touch input, the touch keyboard appears automatically.
segment.target: When the user sets the input focus to a text control by using touch input, the touch keyboard appears automatically.

segment.source: When the input focus is not on a text control, the touch keyboard is hidden.
segment.target: When the input focus is not on a text control, the touch keyboard is hidden.

segment.source: When the touch keyboard appears, it automatically repositions your UI to ensure that the focused element remains visible.
segment.target: When the touch keyboard appears, it automatically repositions your UI to ensure that the focused element remains visible.

segment.source: This can cause other important areas of your UI to move off screen.
segment.target: This can cause other important areas of your UI to move off screen.

segment.source: However, you can disable the default behavior and make your own UI adjustments when the touch keyboard appears.
segment.target: However, you can disable the default behavior and make your own UI adjustments when the touch keyboard appears.

segment.source: For more info, see Responding to the appearance of the on-screen keyboard sample.
segment.target: For more info, see Responding to the appearance of the on-screen keyboard sample.

segment.source: If you create a custom control that requires text input, but does not derive from a standard text input control, you can add touch keyboard support by implementing the correct UI Automation control patterns.
segment.target: If you create a custom control that requires text input, but does not derive from a standard text input control, you can add touch keyboard support by implementing the correct UI Automation control patterns.

segment.source: For more info, see Respond to the presence of the touch keyboard and the Touch keyboard sample.
segment.target: For more info, see Respond to the presence of the touch keyboard and the Touch keyboard sample.

segment.source: Key presses on the touch keyboard raise KeyDown and KeyUp events just like key presses on hardware keyboards.
segment.target: Key presses on the touch keyboard raise KeyDown and KeyUp events just like key presses on hardware keyboards.

segment.source: However, the touch keyboard will not raise input events for Ctrl+A, Ctrl+Z, Ctrl+X, Ctrl+C, and Ctrl+V, which are reserved for text manipulation in the input control.
segment.target: However, the touch keyboard will not raise input events for Ctrl+A, Ctrl+Z, Ctrl+X, Ctrl+C, and Ctrl+V, which are reserved for text manipulation in the input control.

segment.source: You can make it much faster and easier for users to enter data in your app by setting the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data you expect the user to enter.
segment.target: You can make it much faster and easier for users to enter data in your app by setting the input scope of the text control to match the kind of data you expect the user to enter.

segment.source: The input scope provides a hint at the type of text input expected by the control so the system can provide a specialized touch keyboard layout for the input type.
segment.target: The input scope provides a hint at the type of text input expected by the control so the system can provide a specialized touch keyboard layout for the input type.

segment.source: For example, if a text box is used only to enter a 4-digit PIN, set the InputScope property to Number.
segment.target: For example, if a text box is used only to enter a 4-digit PIN, set the InputScope property to Number.

segment.source: This tells the system to show the numeric keypad layout, which makes it easier for the user to enter the PIN.
segment.target: This tells the system to show the numeric keypad layout, which makes it easier for the user to enter the PIN.

segment.source: For more detail, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.
segment.target: For more detail, see Use input scope to change the touch keyboard.
